Description: Mould-made pottery oil-lamp with a double-convex body, a long splayed flat-topped nozzle with a curved tip, a circular base-ring, and a leaf-shaped lug on each side. The filling-hole is surrounded by a double moulding. The shoulder is decorated with an incised key pattern, between the outer moulding of the filling-hole and a single moulding above the carination. On top of the nozzle is a ribboned thyrsos between two raised ridges, which end in volutes. The red-brown surface is perhaps slipped. Dark red-brown Nile silt fabric with abundant mica inclusions. Broken centre opening, hole in side.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Sir William Matthew Flinders Petrie
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Fine Arts, Boston. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Late 3rd to early 2nd century BC parallel from Alexandria (Mlynarczyk 1998, 331-4, Fig. 4d). Parallels dated either late 2nd to 1st or late 3rd to 2nd century BC (Mlynarczyk 1997, 54-7, Type G, Figs. 65-6, who prefers early to mid 2nd century BC date). Mlynarczyk, J. 1997. Alexandrian and Alexandria-influenced mould-made lamps of the Hellenistic period. BAR International Series 677. Mlynarczyk, J. 1998. Terracotta mould-made lamps in Alexandria (Hellenistic to Late Roman period), in Empereur, J-Y. (ed.), Commerce et Artisant dans l’Alexandrie Hellénistique et Romaine, Paris, 327-52.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KD.022) (Phase 3)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Museum of Fine Arts, Boston
Additional IDs: Miscellaneous number: P.4853 (Pottery & Porcelain Ledger No.)
